channel.title: Is game programming a bad or good choice for futher eduction?
channel.description:
I don't actually need to decide this yet, but is game programmer a good profession? I'm thinking a bit about what to do with my future, so I don't need to get in a hurry next spring. From my view this moment, it sounds like a interesting choice and the salary is not bad either. So what are your opinions.
If not, what other programming related education/profession would be smart to choose.
And just another question, I did felt to make another tread about: What is good way to improve your vocal English, of course I could just search on Google, but any tip on some great resources/tricks? English is my second language if it wasn't apparently. My pronunciation is terrible, I can clearly hear my own errors, so just practice speaking would not be that effective, as you don't learn anything by repeating errors.
[b]Extra info:[/b] The course I'm considering does not limit myself to only game programming if that isn't the case with all education in this direction. But it would be a waste of money and time to choose something that won't give me a job, when I could save money and get a good job in another area, being a little country (Norway) it is not many schools to choose from.
[b]Extra question:[/b] What personal attributes are important for a game programmer?
[sup]Just pasting some links for myself to find for later, and for other who are reading this thread and are interested more: http://www.studyincanada.com/english/careers/interview.asp?interview=57[/sup]

item.dc:creator: @bowserjr2 Bowser jr
item.description:
@bowserjr2 wrote:

[quote=“R.I.P RSC, post:6, topic:378325”]Tune in on BBC daily. There are only a few languages that share the same vowels with the English language. Of course it shares some, but not all. So the only way to learn them is to hear them, and repeat them. I guess recording your own pronunciation and listening to the recordings helps too, because of the difference between what you hear and what sounds you actually make.

I learnt English thanks to TV and using the computer. You don’t learn many grammar rules that way though, so that’s my weakness.[/quote]
I watch a lot of television on Internet without subtitles, so I will try to repeat it.

I can't really help with the main question though. Is there a big difference between programming, and game development? IMO you should take a class in programming, and develop games in your spare time.
I have for long had it in my head to make some games, and have already some ideas. So I will follow both your tips, regardless of what I choose in a year time.

item.dc:creator: @tL tL
item.description:
@tL wrote:

As many game developers will tell you. As a programmer, you will likely go through a good few jobs in studios developing games you don’t want to be involved in, but will have to accept because of the experience that many studios require of you.

If you can accept you may be working on Barbie horse adventures as your first job, or Petzzzz 38424 for the DS, before you get into games that you’re genuinely interested in - then go for it!

item.title: Is game programming a bad or good choice for futher eduction?
item.dc:creator: @Mopman Mopman
item.description:
@Mopman wrote:

In my opinion (and this is just my opinion, remember, I’m not a game developer) game development is a good choice of profession if you LOVE it. And I mean, LOVE it.

It pays a lot less than equivalently-skilled development positions in other industries, and it’s harder to get into, and often much harder work. But you get to work on cool games. Whether that makes up for it in your opinion is your choice.

As for the english problem, just speak to people a lot. There’s a website, www.lang-8.com, which hooks language learners up with native speakers for practice, in a tit-for-tat fashion (you correct me in English, I’ll correct you in my tongue etc.) It’s aimed more at the written word, but I’m pretty sure I remember quite a few people being up for skyping and stuff.

If not, just make a point of Skyping with more people instead of IM’ing them/email’ing, and make it clear that they should ruthlessly correct your pronunciation or mistakes. Most people don’t mind doing it, I’ve found, but they’re shy or embarassed or whatever of doing it without your permission, because they sound like a dick. If you make it clear that you want to improve they’ll gladly help.

item.title: Is game programming a bad or good choice for futher eduction?
item.dc:creator: @Mr.Chris Mr.Chris
item.description:
@Mr.Chris wrote:

I’m not sure that’s your best option at such an early stage. So few jobs for such a select few if you plan to make a decent living out of it.

I’d reccomend that you keep as many doors open to you as possible. If you want to go down the programming route, pick some course/profession that will encompas that, but also several other areas of computing. That way you can gain a more clear idea of what you really want to do.

Vocal English? Do you mean english isn’t your first language or your just not projecting your voice? Either way, practice!!

Just keep options open, but if game programming is a real passion and something you well and truly wish to do for a career, go for it!!!
